subtitle: Did you know that the famed Greek hero Achilles, hailing from ancient Greece, transcended mere
mythology to be a real individual, existing as a demigod amidst the turmoil of the Trojan
Wars? Achilles, born of the union between an extraterrestrial sea goddess and a mortal Greek
king, emerged as the most celebrated warrior of his time. He not only clashed in a legendary duel
with Prince Hector of Troy but also faced off against King Memnon, the formidable
warrior of Ethiopia. Recent archaeological discoveries near Turkey have unearthed remnants
of this war once believe to be myth and now shedding new light on the ancient battlegrounds.
In the mythical and ancient historical texts of Plato's poem The Illiad,
Achilles stands as the paramount perfect warrior, a paragon of flawless prowess and style. His might
mirrors the strength of Hercules and biblical Samson, his perception rivals the keen instincts
of the greek hero Perseus, and his spirit and skills evoke the warrior essence of
the legendary gladiator Spartacus. Legend whispers that no mortal could wound him,
for the half man half god embodied death and supreme skill in human form,
ushering all souls to the heavy pitts of the underworld, known as the realm of Hades.
Long ago in the 12 century BC, In the ancient city of Thessaly, a child was born to the water goddess
Thetis and a human king named Peleus. Zeus, the king of the gods and Poseidon, god of the sea,
had both fallen in love with Thetis and were rivals for her hand in marriage. However,
King Pelus was one of the most famous mortal kings of the ancient greek realm, his adventures as an
Argonaut retrieving the golden fleece was widespread. Together Thetis and Peleus had
their love child and they named him Achilles in greek meaning "achoes" one who gives great pain.
The shadow of prophecy loomed over Achilles from his infancy. According to greek myth,
Thetis, foreseeing her son's fated demise, sought to protect him. In a secret ritual,
she dipped him in the river of Styx, granting him invulnerability. However, the end of his
heel by which she held him remained untouched by the magical waters. Under the tutelage of Thetis,
Achilles delved into the cosmic arts of ancient mysteries. As a goddess,
Thetis held the privilege of accessing Mount Olympus, the celestial abode of the gods in
the heavens, where she proudly presented her son at numerous divine gatherings. The gods,
aware of Achilles' foretold destiny as the greatest hero, marveled at his
presence. Achilles embodied strength, courage, and loyalty. Zeus himself even claimed him as a son.
As a young child, Achilles was entrusted to the wise centaur Chiron, Chiron,
residing on Mount Pelion, was the foremost warrior instructor of all ancient Greece,
crafting intricate war training apparatus to hone the skills of renowned warriors
and fighters of all time. Achilles was his greatest student. Under Chiron's guidance,
the young hero learned the arts of war and wisdom. It was during these formative years that he forged
a deep friendship with younger cousin Patroclus who would stand by him through joy and tragedy.
However, with the passage of time, Achilles matured on the earthly realm,
and his perception of the great gods he knew underwent a profound shift. No longer did he hold
the same respect and reverence for the divine beings who lived on mount olympus. Instead,
he witnessed their vulnerabilities, their all-too-human qualities.
In manhood, He earned renown all over greece for his mighty exploits in battle. His reputation was
that he was unbeatable, fearless and so skilled with a sword that kings and gods gave away their
riches to see a glimpse of him in combat. It was then he on the greek land of Phthia,
he went toe to toe with a monstrous infamous giant who stood 13 feet tall and defeated it with a
single swing of his sword. Subsequently, Achilles found himself marked by the attention of Apollo,
the sun god and Zeus's own son. This divine encounter transpired after
Achilles had shared intimate moments with a Trojan woman he ardently desired. Aware of
Apollo's formidable power, Achilles stood steadfast, unfazed by the god's descent.
In an audacious move, Apollo, the radiant deity, issued a challenge to Achilles,
proposing a duel of swords. Undaunted, Achilles met the god's gaze and accepted
the divine challenge, setting the stage for a clash that would resonate through
both mortal and celestial realms. A duel between the mortal champion and the divine
sun god. The air crackled with anticipation as Apollo, wreathed in the brilliance of sunlight,
drawing his celestial sword, its blade forged in the fiery heart of the sun.
Achilles, undeterred and resolute, gripped his double edged short sword
with the strength of a demigod. The ground they were located became an arena where half
mortal and immortal forces collided, the very earth trembling beneath their feet.
The clash of steel echoed through the heavens as Apollo and Achilles engaged in a dance of blades.
Each strike from Achilles was met with a dazzling parry from the god, and the very air seemed to
shimmer with the intensity of their conflict. Achilles moved with a swiftness surpassing Apollo
with every swing, darting and maneuvering in ways beyond Apollo's anticipation growing him weary and
tired. In response, Apollo wielded his sword with all his strength, aiming to vanquish Achilles.
In a moment of divine fury, Apollo unleashed the full power of the sun,
sending searing beams of light toward Achilles. Yet, the half mortal hero,
fueled by the essence of skill stood firm, his shield absorbing the celestial onslaught.
Are you sure you are a God? Achilles added with a smirk. He threw his shield at the God Apollo.
In a daring move, Achilles seized this opportunity and delivered a masterful stroke
of his short sword faster than quicksilver, disarming Apollo and leaving him vulnerable,
sword to neck. The god, recognizing his defeat, conceded the duel with a glare that echoed his
divine displeasure. Yet, Apollo's pride was wounded, and a seed of animosity took root.
As Apollo ascended back to the heavens,
a vengeful glare fixed upon Achilles, their once-neutral relationship now tainted with enmity.
As Achilles reputation grew, The tales of his prowess reached the ears of Agamemnon,
the powerful king of Mycenae. He designated Achilles as his premier warrior and rewarded
him as the champion of all Greece. Yet, despite Agamemnon's appointment of Achilles as his
foremost fighter, a mutual animosity persisted between them. Intriguingly, Achilles held a
contrasting sentiment towards King Odysseus, whom he deeply admired. In his quest to conquer Troy,
Agamemnon summoned Achilles and his Myrmidons to join the Greek expedition.
According to greek ancient texts, the Myrmidons were created by Zeus,
the king of the gods, at the request of the sea goddess Thetis. Thetis,
wanting to provide her son Achilles with a devoted and skilled group of warriors, asked
Zeus to transform a colony of ants into human warriors. As a result, the Myrmidons were born.
The name "Myrmidon" is believed to be derived from the Greek word
"myrmex," which means ant. This name is a nod to their mythical origin,
symbolizing their industrious and disciplined nature in battle.
Before embarking on his journey, he rendezvoused with his mother Thetis
beside the azure waters of the Aegean Sea. It was there that she prophesied:
should he refrain from battle, he would live out his days in contentment, yet fade into obscurity
with time. Conversely, should he choose to join the fray, his name would be immortalized for as
long as men had tongues, however at the cost of meeting his own end in the throws of war.
The journey to Troy was fraught with tension as Achilles and Agamemnon,
both prideful and headstrong, clashed over leadership. The princes of Troy,
led by Hector, diligently prepared for the imminent war, fortifying the beach
with spikes in anticipation of the Greek forces' arrival. Meanwhile, Helen of Troy, who had fled
to Troy with Prince Paris from Sparta, wrestled with guilt over the consequences of her love,
foreseeing the impending loss of lives due to the decisions her and him made.
Achilles and his formidable Myrmidons reached the shores of Troy ahead of the other Greek forces.
The mere presence of Achilles commanded the area. As he descended upon the beach,
his armor gleaming, he effortlessly cut through Troy's warriors with a glazing
swings of his sword, leaving them fallen like children. Rallying his men, Achilles directed
them toward a nearby temple of Apollo by the shore. Standing before the temple, he declared
an early victory for their side. Achilles had already taken the beach for the greeks in one
single day even before The king's fleet arrived on the sands. The army of the king still on their
ships bore witness to Achilles's awe-inspiring feats, and in a surge of inspiration, they began
chanting Achilles's name, overshadowing the king's authority. In a bold move,
Achilles severed the head of the Apollo statue to instill fear in the Trojans regarding their god.
During the chaos, male and female priests of the temple, along with a captivating priestess named
Brieis, who happened to be the cousin of the princes of Troy, were taken hostage. Achilles
found himself drawn to Brieis, fostering a peculiar connection amid the turmoil.
As the war unfolded, the battles persisted month after month,
year after year. The Trojans exhibited resilience with impeccable walls and
formidable warriors, setting the stage for a protracted and intense conflict.
During the Trojan War, Achilles found himself embroiled in a fierce battle that would lead him
to face Memnon, the prince of Ethiopia, who sided with troy on the battlefield. The roots of their
confrontation lie in Achilles' quest for vengeance and the alliances forged amidst the chaos of war.
As the Greek forces besieged the city of Troy, Achilles, the greatest of the Greek warriors,
was consumed by a burning desire to avenge the death of his beloved companion,
Patroclus, who had been slain by the Trojan prince Hector. Driven by grief and fury,
Achilles emerged from his self-imposed exile ENRAGED AND rejoined the Greek army,
his legendary armor gleaming in the sunlight as he RODE HIS chariot to the front gates of Troy,
to battle Prince Hector IN COMBAT for revenge of the killing of his cousin.
Prince Hector in his armor and wield with sword
walks up to the fierce warrior in the front gates and says.
"I've seen this moment in my dreams. I'll make a pact with you. With the gods as our witnesses,
let us pledge that the winner will allow the loser all the proper funeral rituals.
Achilles responds "There are no pacts between lions and men." He then stabs
his spear into the ground, and takes off his helmet, throwing it to the side.
Achilles said, Now you know who you're fighting.
Hector then takes off helmet and throws it aside.
"I thought it was you I was fighting yesterday. And I wish it had been,
but I gave the dead boy the honor he deserved."
Achilles then said, You gave him the honor of your sword. You won't have eyes tonight;
you won't have ears or a tongue. You will wander the underworld blind, deaf, and dumb,
and all the dead will know: This is Hector. The fool who thought he killed Achilles."
After Achilles slaughtered the great and beloved
prince of troy. He dragged his body back to camp, in an act of disrespect towards
the people of troy and to the prince who asked for proper funeral rights.
Meanwhile, Memnon, the valiant prince of Ethiopia, had answered the call to
arms issued by King Priam of Troy, eager to defend the city against the invading
Greeks. Possessing unparalleled skill in battle and a heart brimming with courage,
Memnon rallied his troops and prepared to meet the enemy head-on.
As the conflict raged on, Achilles and Memnon each carved a path of destruction through the opposing
forces, their names becoming synonymous with bravery and prowess on the battlefield. he sun,
a fiery chariot, cast its golden rays upon the battlefield, illuminating the confrontation
between these two formidable champions. Achilles, the indomitable Greek hero,
stood tall and resolute, his gleaming armor reflecting the light of day. Opposite him
stood Memnon, the Ethiopian prince, a figure of unparalleled strength and valor,
his ebony skin glistening with sweat beneath the blazing sun.
The air crackled with tension as the two warriors locked eyes,
each recognizing in the other a worthy adversary. With a mighty roar, Achilles charged forward,
his spear held high, a blur of bronze in motion. Memnon met his advance head-on, his own weapon,
a towering spear fashioned from the heart of a mighty oak, poised for battle.
Their clash was thunderous, the sound of steel meeting steel reverberating across
the battlefield. Achilles' spear flashed like lightning, seeking out chinks in Memnon's armor,
while Memnon's blows rained down with the force of a tempest,
testing the limits of Achilles' legendary invulnerability.
Again and again, they clashed, their weapons a blur of motion
as they danced the deadly dance of combat. Achilles, fueled by rage and determination,
fought with the ferocity of a wounded lion, his every strike a testament to his unmatched
skill and prowess. Yet Memnon, undaunted by the fury of his opponent, matched him blow for blow,
his movements fluid and precise, a testament to years of training and discipline.
As the battle raged on, the tide of fortune shifted back and forth,
neither warrior able to gain the upper hand. With each passing moment, the stakes grew higher,
the fate of nations hanging in the balance. Achilles, driven by the memory of past glory and
the promise of eternal renown, fought with the fury of a man possessed, while Memnon,
defending his homeland and his people, fought with the unwavering resolve of a true hero.
But in the end, it was Achilles who emerged victorious, his final blow striking true and
felling Memnon where he stood. With a triumphant cry, Achilles raised his bloodied spear to the
heavens, a testament to his victory over one of the greatest warriors he had ever battled.
During the climactic siege of the Trojan Wars, within the depths of Troy's city walls,
Achilles suffered a fatal blow when Prince Paris of Troy aimed an arrow at his Achilles
heel. Despite enduring numerous battle wounds and sword slashes, it was this single strike to
his heel that proved to be Achilles' downfall and late demise inside the burning city of Troy.
The tale of Achilles, the greatest warrior to ever live, as chronicled in the Iliad,
has captivated hearts and minds for millennia even being idolized by ancients after him such
as Alexander The Great and Julius Cesar, encapsulating the triumphs and tragedies
inherent in the human condition. His journey resonates through the ages, echoing in the annals
of mythologyâ€”a term which, to the ancients, represented their living history. Thank you
for joining us in this retelling of an immortal saga, that was once believed to be mythology.
We invite you to share your thoughts on the great warrior Achilles in the comments below. If you
enjoyed this episode, please like, share, and subscribe to Astral Legends for more captivating
explorations of ancient mysteries and legends. May the eternal light illuminate your path
always. Until next time, farewell, and may the journey ahead be filled with wonder and discovery.
If you like this episode, please like share and subscribe to Astral Legends
for more ancient mysteries and legends. May the
eternal light forever guide your path. See you on the next episode.
